text: We will hear arguments next in 1529 Henderson against Morgan.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
He was there as a patient?
He was there as patient, Your Honor.

Mr. Lewittes, does the New York make what I think of as a customary distinction between the first-degree murder and the second-degree murder that first degree would require a predisposition as well as intent, while at second-degree intent would be sufficient without predisposition or premeditation?
That is correct.
It was not orally argued.
It was not
If you know about the tendency of the application for Certificate of Probable Cause, did your office know?
We did not know at that time.
Although, this was --
That is correct.
Does a statute or rule require notice, I wonder?
I do not believe that it does.
(Inaudible), is there any practice at all relating the notice that you are familiar with?
I can say Justice Brennan that there is no hard and fast rule.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
You mean that that (Inaudible) circumstances rule?
I do, your Honor.
Do you think the Second Circuit did?
Yes.
In this case?
In this case, very definitely Your Honor, if I may explain.
How do you explain the Court relying on Rule 11 in the McCarthy case?
No, I do not think that this case stands for proposition as counsel has suggested that this means that every --
McCarthy decided in the opinion, it is not?
The opinion says that the plea must be voluntary.
The crucial elements of those of the totality of circumstances starting I suppose with the fact that he had counsel or you would concede that was --
That would be pertinent very definitely Your Honor.
But you have to inquire whether this was experience Counsel?
Yes.
Do you think its passes those two tests here?
Yes, I have no quarrel with the conduct of the defense counsel here.
Mr. Lynch, Judge Port originally found that it had been a voluntary and intelligent plea, and then the Second Circuit reversed.
That is correct, Your Honor.
And at Page 10 that very short opinion of the Second Circuit or at Page 10A of your petition.
It certainly suggests that the Second Circuit thought it was important, but that does not mean I believe that in deciding this case Judge Port looked only at that issue.
But then let me interruption you and then go ahead and answer as much.
I respectfully disagree, Your Honor, because in Judge Portâ€™s original decision there had been no evidentiary hearing.
He does not say he did though.
Oh no! That is true.
What you can say that is just the other side of the -- but requiring on guilty plea -- you are supposed to put on the record if the elements that go to guilty plea.
Under the Federal rules as I understand them that is correct.
It is under Boykin too.
Yes.
Under Boykin, and so may we assume that the Judge put up record the elements that he relied on in overturning the guilty plea?

Yes, I think you may assumed that I would like to have you also assume what I think is a valid assumption that when a Judge says I am going to take into consideration all of the circumstances that is what he does.
First time or the second time.
The second intent.
